The '''General Mobile Radio Service''' (GMRS) is a land-mobile [[frequency modulation|FM]] [[Ultra high frequency|UHF]] [[radio]] service designed for short-distance two-way communication. It requires a license in [[United States]] but some GMRS compatible equipment can be used license-free in [[Canada]]. The United States permits use by adult individuals who possesses a valid GMRS license, as well as their immediate family members.The FCC definition of “immediate family” includes the licensee’s spouse, children, stepchildren, parents, stepparents, siblings, grandparents, aunts, uncles, nephews, nieces, and in-laws. See 47 [[Code of Federal Regulations|CFR]] 95.179 . Immediate relatives of the GMRS system licensee are entitled to communicate among themselves for personal or business purposes, but employees of the licensee who are not family members are not covered by the license   non-family members must be licensed separately. GMRS radios are typically handheld portable devices much like [[Family Radio Service]] (FRS) radios, and share the FRS frequency band near 462 and 467 MHz. Mobile and base station-style radios are available as well, but these are normally commercial UHF radios as often used in the public service and commercial land mobile bands. These are legal for use in this service as long as they are GMRS type-approved. ==Licensing== Any individual in the United States who is at least 18 years of age and not a representative of a foreign government may apply for a GMRS license by completing the application form, either on paper or online through the FCC's Universal Licensing System. No exam is required. A GMRS license is issued for a 10 year term.{{cite web |publisher=FCC |title=GMRS Information |url=https://www.fcc.gov/general-mobile-radio-service-gmrs}} The fee is $70 for most applicants.{{cite web |publisher=FCC |title=GMRS fee schedule |url=http://wireless.fcc.gov/feesforms/feeguide/services/generalmobile.pdf}} A GMRS individual license extends to immediate family members and authorizes them to use the licensed system.{{cite web |title=Title 47 → Chapter I → Subchapter D → Part 95 → Subpart A → §95.179 |url=http://www.ecfr.gov/cgi-bin/text-idx?SID=7f586db1d0579e3dbf18c41914a8fe14&mc=true&node=se47.5.95_1179&rgn=div8 |website=Electronic Code of Federal Regulations |accessdate=26 June 2016}} GMRS license holders are allowed to communicate with FRS users on those frequencies that are shared between the two services. GMRS individual licenses do not extend to employees. New GMRS licenses are being issued only to individuals. Prior to 31 July 1987, the FCC issued GMRS licenses to non-individuals (corporations, partnerships, government entities, etc.). These licensees are [[Grandfather clause|grandfathered]] and may renew but not make major modifications to their existing licenses.{{cite web |url=http://wireless.fcc.gov/services/index.htm?job=licensing_1&id=general_mobile |publisher=FCC |series=Wireless Services: General Mobile Radio Service |title=Licensing: Eligibility}} In any case, each GMRS station must be identified by transmission of its FCC-assigned call sign at the end of a transmission or a series of transmissions, and at least once every 15 minutes for a series lasting more than 15 minutes. The call sign may be spoken or sent with audible tones using Morse code. A repeater station handling properly identified transmissions of others is not required to send its own station identification (47 CFR §95.1751). ==Range== As with other UHF radio services, reliable range is considered to be [[Line-of-sight propagation|line-of-sight]] and the distance to the [[Line-of-sight propagation#Radio horizon|radio horizon]] can be estimated based on antenna height. Theoretically, the range between two hand-held units would be about one or two miles (about 1.5–3 km); mobile units have higher antennas and a range of around 5 miles (8 km). A GMRS [[repeater]] with an antenna that is high above the surrounding terrain can extend the usable range over a wide area – for example, up to a 20 mile (32.2 km) radius around the repeater station.{{cite book |first=H. Ward |last=Silver |title=Two-way radios & scanners for dummies |publisher=For Dummies |year=2005 |ISBN=0-7645-9582-2 |page=56}} Obstructions such as hills and buildings can reduce range. Higher power does not necessarily give a proportional increase in range, although it may improve the reliability of communication at the limits of line-of-sight distance. == Frequency assignments and FRS == The GMRS-only channels are defined in pairs, with one frequency in the 462 MHz range for [[Simplex communication|simplex]] and [[repeater]] outputs, and another in the 467 MHz frequency range for repeater inputs. There are eight channels exclusively for GMRS and seven "interstitial" channels shared with Family Radio Service. GMRS use requires an FCC license, and licensees are permitted to transmit at up to 50 [[watt]]s on GMRS frequencies, depending on the type of station,{{cite web |url=http://ecfr.gpoaccess.gov/cgi/t/text/text-idx?c=ecfr&rgn=div5&view=text&node=47:5.0.1.1.5&idno=47#47:5.0.1.1.5.1.139.21 |title=Electronic Code of Federal Regulations, Title 47 |at=§95.135 |publisher=Federal Communications Commission |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111108214031/http://ecfr.gpoaccess.gov/cgi/t/text/text-idx?c=ecfr&sid=33d962284348d5bf6c78f7cc44b19e66&rgn=div5&view=text&node=47%3A5.0.1.1.5&idno=47#47:5.0.1.1.5.1.139.21 |archivedate=2011-11-08 |df=dmy-all}} but 1 to 5 Watts is more common. Units are allowed to have detachable or external antennas. GMRS licensees are also able to use the first seven of the FRS frequencies (the "interstitial" GMRS frequencies) with a few limitations. Specifically, they may be used as long as one-way pages are not transmitted, communications are limited to voice, and transmission power ([[Effective radiated power|ERP]]) does not exceed 5 Watts (FCC Code §95.29, section f). This allows GMRS users to transmit on a total of 15 channels. FRS channels 8 through 14 are not available for GMRS use; use of these frequencies requires an FRS transceiver, or a hybrid transceiver operating under FRS rules.{{cite web |url=http://ecfr.gpoaccess.gov/cgi/t/text/text-idx?c=ecfr&sid=5447912ed1c106cb636130d863edb44e&rgn=div5&view=text&node=47:5.0.1.1.5&idno=47 |title=ECFR |website=GPOAccess.gov}}{{cite book |author=[http://www.fcc.gov/ Federal Communications Commission] |work=Code of Federal Regulations, Title 47 |series=Telecommunication Chapter 1 — Federal Communications Commission, Part 95 |title=Personal Radio Services |publisher=United States Government Printing Office |at=§95.29; §95.603(a); §95.603(d); §95.621; §95.627 |url=http://www.gpo.gov/fdsys/pkg/CFR-2009-title47-vol5/pdf/CFR-2009-title47-vol5-part95.pdf}} Hybrid FRS/GMRS consumer radios have been introduced with 22 channels, instead of the 14 channels associated with FRS. On this type of radio, transmitting on shared FRS/GMRS channels 1–7 requires a license if using more than 0.5 Watt. Channels 8–14 are strictly license-free FRS channels. Transmitting on GMRS-only channels 15–22 requires a license. It is the responsibility of the radio user to read and understand all applicable rules and regulations regarding GMRS. These hybrid radios are often referred to as "bubble pack" radios, since they are often packed in a plastic shell, for hanging on a display shelf. The massive sales of these radios have led to the term "bubble-pack [[Pirate radio|pirates]]", persons who use GMRS without a license.{{cite news |author=Cantor, Andrew |newspaper=USAToday.com |title=CyberSpeak - Walkie-talkies still fit in the dreams of little boys |publisher=USA Today division of Gannett Co. Inc. |date=2005-01-07 |accessdate=2011-03-11 |url=https://www.usatoday.com/tech/columnist/andrewkantor/2005-01-07-kantor_x.htm |df=dmy-all}} Effective 28 September 2017, FCC revised the definition of the FRS service. FRS operation is now permitted with up to 2 Watts on the shared FRS / GMRS channels. The FCC will not grant type acceptance for hybrid radios that would exceed the limits for the FRS service on the FRS channels. Current "hybrid" FRS/GMRS radios will not require a GMRS license for power up to 2 Watts, but FRS radios will still not be permitted to use the input frequencies of GMRS repeaters. Any radio exceeding the limits of the new FRS service will be classified as a GMRS radio.{{cite web |url=http://transition.fcc.gov/Daily_Releases/Daily_Business/2017/db0522/FCC-17-57A1.pdf |title=FCC Part 95 Personal Radio Services Rules Reform |publisher=Federal Communications Commission |accessdate=May 19, 2017 |quote=Paragraphs 51 and 52 list the changes on the FRS / GMRS channels and power restrictions. These modifications are meant to affect previous FRS / GMRS hybrid radios in the United State that were commonly sold to redefine them as FRS radios, since many users that purchase these radios did not know the FCC license requirements. As a result, these users will not require a GMRS license. Radios transmitting higher than the new FRS power restrictions are re-defined as GMRS radios and users will require a GMRS license to use these devices. The changes (channels and power limitations) went into effect on 28 September 2017. |df=dmy-all}} The FCC rules for use of hybrid radios on channels 1–7 require licensing only when operating under the rules that apply to the GMRS.{{cite web |url=http://wireless.fcc.gov/services/index.htm?job=service_home&id=general_mobile |title=General Mobile Radio Service |access-date=2011-01-31 |df=dmy-all}} Many hybrid radios have an ERP that is lower than a half-watt on channels 1–7, or can be set by the user to operate at low power on these channels. This allows hybrid radios to be used under the license-free FRS rules if the ERP is less than one half watt and the unit is certified for FRS operation. Only two makers of hybrid FRS / GMRS radios (Garmin and Motorola) presently sell radios that will operate on the GMRS repeater channels; the common "22 channel" radios cannot be used with GMRS repeaters. The Icom IC-F21GM is a solely-GMRS radio that will also work with repeaters. FRS rules permit only 2.5 kHz ([[Narrowband FM]]) [[frequency deviation]] on the FRS shared channels. GMRS uses ±5 kHz [[Frequency Modulation#deviation|deviation]] on the GMRS channels. Effective 30 September 2019, it becomes unlawful in the USA to import, manufacture, sell, or offer to sell radio equipment capable of operating under both GMRS and FRS.{{cite web |url=https://www.federalregister.gov/documents/2017/08/29/2017-17395/personal-radio-service-reform |title=47 CFR § 95.1792 |series=Personal Radio Service reform |date=29 August 2017}} New GMRS/FRS Frequency chart effective 28 September 2017. {|class="wikitable" ! Notes |- | "FRS 8" || "5625" || 467.5625 MHz || FRS use only. |- | "FRS 9" || "5875" || 467.5875 MHz || FRS use only. |- | "FRS 10" || "6125" || 467.6125 MHz || FRS use only. |- | "FRS 11" || "6375" || 467.6375 MHz || FRS use only. |- | "FRS 12" || "6625" || 467.6625 MHz || FRS use only. |- | "FRS 13" || "6875" || 467.6875 MHz || FRS use only. |- | "FRS 14" || "7125" || 467.7125 MHz || FRS use only. |- |} ==History== The predecessor to GMRS was named '''Class A Citizens Radio Service''' when it was rolled out in the 1960s. Tube type transceivers were used, and transmitter power was limited to 60 watts (plate input power to the final amplifier tube). The original service ran wideband FM with ±15 kHz transmitter deviation and 50 kHz channel spacing. At the time, this was the norm for all U.S. land mobile services. There was also a Class B Citizens Radio Service which used a different set of 461 MHz channels and was limited to 5 Watts output. Business users were permitted to license in this radio service. Radios were built by consumer electronics firms and commercial two-way radio vendors. In the 1960s, the UHF 450–470 MHz band was re-allocated to 25 kHz channels. This meant transmitter deviation was reduced to ±5 kHz. This doubled the number of channels available across the entire 450–470 MHz band. Class B Citizens Radio Service channels were re-allocated to other radio services. In the 1970s, allowed power was again changed to 50 Watts across the output terminals of the transmitter. In 1987, licensing of business users was discontinued and businesses were allowed to continue operating until their licenses expired. There was congestion on all channels in larger [[metropolitan statistical area]]s and moving businesses to [[Business band|Business Radio Service]] channels would provide some relief. The radio service was changed to its present name; General Mobile Radio Service or GMRS. In 2010 the [[U.S. Federal Communications Commission]] (FCC) proposed removing the individual licensing requirement. In 2015, the FCC ruled to keep the license requirement, but to remove the regulator fee for licensing.{{cite web |url=http://transition.fcc.gov/Daily_Releases/Daily_Business/2015/db0521/FCC-15-59A1.pdf |title=FCC-15-59A1 |series=Daily Releases |format=pdf}} Adopted on 20 May 2015, the ruling would be in effect after a 90 day notification period to Congress; the fee will not be eliminated before 18 August 2015.{{cite web |url=http://transition.fcc.gov/Daily_Releases/Daily_Business/2015/db0521/FCC-15-59A1.pdf |title=FCC-15-59A1 |format=pdf |page=9}} The fee for a 5 year license was $90.00, with the regulatory fee portion of the license at $5 per year (or $25 for the 5 year life of the license). After the notification period, the fee for a 5 year license was to become $65.00 . The change became effective on 3 September 2015. ==Use of GMRS equipment in other countries== The use of radio transmitters is regulated by national laws and international agreements. Often radio equipment accepted for use in one part of the world may not be operated in other parts due to conflicts with frequency assignments and technical standards. Some of the roles that the licensed GMRS service fills in the United States are, in other countries, filled by unlicensed or class-licensed services. Generally these services have strict technical standards for equipment to prevent interference with licensed transmitters and systems. In [[Canada]], hand-held GMRS radios up to 2 Watts have been approved for use without a license since September 2004.{{cite book |publisher=Industry Canada |id=RSS 210 |title=Low-Power Licence Exempt Radiocommunications Devices}} Typically these are dual FRS and GMRS units, with fixed antennas, and operating at 2 Watts on some GMRS channels and 0.5 Watt on the FRS-only channels. Mobile units (permanently mounted in vehicles), [[base station]]s and [[Radio repeater|repeater]]s are not currently permitted on the GMRS channels in Canada. Other countries have licensed and unlicensed personal radio services with somewhat similar characteristics, but technical details and operating conditions vary according to national rules. Many European countries use a similar 8 channel system near 446 MHz known as [[PMR446]], as well as a 69 channel low-power [[LPD433]] which is shared with the [[ISM band]]. GMRS equipment that is approved for use in the United States will not communicate with PMR446 radios due to using different frequency ranges. ==See also== *[[Family Radio Service]] *[[Multi-Use Radio Service]] ==References== {{Reflist|refs= {{cite web |url = https://www.fcc.gov/encyclopedia/general-mobile-radio-service-gmrs |title = General Mobile Radio Service (GMRS) |publisher = Federal Communications Commission |accessdate = November 11, 2015 |quote = [U]se of frequencies 462.650, 467.6500, 462.7000 and 467.7000 MHz is not permitted near the Canadian border[.] |df=dmy-all}} }} ==Clarification== {{Reflist|group=lower-alpha}} ==External links== *{{cite web |url=http://wireless.fcc.gov/services/personal/generalmobile/ |publisher=FCC |title=GMRS Specifications and U.S. licensing information}} *{{cite web |url=http://wireless.fcc.gov/services/index.htm?job=service_bandplan&id=family |publisher=FCC |title=FRS Band Plan}} *{{cite web |url=http://nwigmrs.com/repeaters.html |title=Example nonprofit GMRS Repeater}} *{{cite web |url=https://www.mygmrs.com/ |title=MyGMRS.com Repeater Directory}} {{Two-way radio}} {{Telecommunications}} [[Category:Bandplans]] [[Category:Radio technology]] [[Category:Radio regulations]]

{{short description|cloud storage and file synchronization service from Google}} {{Use mdy dates|date=March 2017}} {{Infobox website | logo = [[File:Google Drive logo.svg|100px]] | screenshot = Google Drive screenshot.png | caption = The web version of Google Drive | url = {{URL|google.com/drive|Google.com/Drive}} | type = [[File hosting service]] | registration = Required | num_users = 1 billion (July 2018){{Citation needed|reason=Anonymous edit on July 26|date=August 2018}} | owner = [[Google|Google LLC]] | launch_date = {{start date and age|2012|04|24}} | alexa = | name = Google Drive }}
'''Google Drive''' is a [[File hosting service|file storage]] and [[File synchronization|synchronization service]] developed by [[Google]]. Launched on April 24, 2012, Google Drive allows users to store files on their servers, synchronize files across devices, and [[file sharing|share files]]. In addition to a [[web application|website]], Google Drive offers apps with offline capabilities for [[Microsoft Windows|Windows]] and [[macOS]] computers, and [[Android (operating system)|Android]] and [[iOS]] smartphones and tablets. Google Drive encompasses [[Google Docs, Sheets and Slides]], an [[office suite]] that permits collaborative editing of documents, spreadsheets, presentations, drawings, forms, and more. Files created and edited through the office suite are saved in Google Drive.
Google Drive offers users with 15 [[gigabyte]]s of free storage though [[Google One]]. Google One also offers 100 gigabytes, 200 gigabytes, 2 [[Terabyte|terabytes]] 10 terabytes, 20 terabytes, and 30 terabytes offered through optional paid plans. Files uploaded can be up to 5 terabytes in size. Users can change privacy settings for individual files and folders, including enabling sharing with other users or making content public. On the website, users can search for an image by describing its visuals, and use [[natural language processing|natural language]] to find specific files, such as "find my budget spreadsheet from last December".
The website and Android app offer a Backups section to see what Android devices have data backed up to the service, and a completely overhauled computer app released in July 2017 allows for backing up specific folders on the user's computer. A Quick Access feature can [[Machine learning|intelligently predict]] the files users need.
Google Drive is a key component of [[G Suite]], Google's monthly subscription offering for businesses and organizations. As part of select G Suite plans, Drive offers unlimited storage, advanced file audit reporting, enhanced administration controls, and greater collaboration tools for teams.
Following the launch of the service, Google Drive privacy policy was heavily criticized by some members of the media. Google has one set of Terms of Service and Privacy Policy agreements that cover all of its services, meaning that the language in the agreements grants the company broad rights to reproduce, use, and create [[derivative work]]s from content stored on Google Drive. While the policies also confirm that users retain intellectual property rights, privacy advocates raised concerns that the licenses grant Google the rights to use the information and data to customize advertising and other services Google provides. In contrast, other members of the media noted that the agreements were no worse than those of competing cloud storage services, but that the competition uses "more artful language" in the agreements, and also stated that Google needs the rights in order to "move files around on its servers, cache your data, or make image thumbnails".
{{As of|2017|3}}, Google Drive has 800 million active users, and as of September 2015, it has over one million organizational paying users. {{As of|2017|5}}, there are over two trillion files stored on the service.
== Platforms == {{infobox software | name = Google Drive Android app | logo = Google Drive logo.svg | screenshot = Screenshot of Google Drive app for Android.png | operating system = [[Windows]], [[macOS]], [[Chrome OS]], [[Android (operating system)|Android]], [[iOS]] | programming language = [[Python (programming language)|Python]] (back-end), [[Objective-C]] (Mac client), [[wxPython]] (Windows client)<ref>{{cite web |title=Open source components and licenses |url=https://support.google.com/drive/answer/1716931 |website=Drive Help |publisher=[[Google]] |accessdate=March 7, 2017}}</ref> | ver layout = stacked | license = [[Freeware]] | website = {{url|https://www.google.com/drive/}} | caption = Google Drive's [[Android (operating system)|Android]] app }}
Google Drive was introduced on April 24, 2012 with apps available for [[Microsoft Windows|Windows]], [[macOS]], and [[Android (operating system)|Android]], as well as a [[web application|website interface]].<ref name="Introducing Google Drive">{{cite web |first=Sundar |last=Pichai |title=Introducing Google Drive... yes, really |url=https://googleblog.blogspot.no/2012/04/introducing-google-drive-yes-really.html |website=Official Google Blog |publisher=[[Google]] |date=April 24, 2012 |accessdate=January 16, 2017}}</ref> The iOS app was released in June 2012.<ref>{{cite web |first=Sean |last=Gallagher |title=Hands-on with the Google Drive for iOS app: mostly read only |url=https://arstechnica.com/information-technology/2012/06/hands-on-with-the-google-drive-for-ios-app-mostly-read-only/ |website=[[Ars Technica]] |publisher=[[Condé Nast]] |date=June 29, 2012 |accessdate=March 18, 2017}}</ref>
=== Computer apps ===
Google Drive is available for PCs running [[Windows 7]] or later, and Macs running [[Mac OS X Lion|OS X Lion]] or later.<ref>{{cite web |title=System requirements and browsers |url=https://support.google.com/drive/answer/2375082 |website=Drive Help |publisher=[[Google]] |accessdate=May 10, 2017}}</ref> Google indicated in April 2012 that work on Linux software was underway,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pcworld.com/article/254488/google_drive_for_linux_is_on_the_way.html|title=Google Drive for Linux Is on the Way|last=Noyes|first=Katherine|date=April 25, 2012|website=[[PC World]]|publisher=[[International Data Group]]|accessdate=January 16, 2017}}</ref> but there was no news on this as of November 2013.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.cnet.com/news/google-drive-for-linux-patience-patience/ |title=Google Drive for Linux? Patience, patience... |last=Shankland |first=Stephen |date=November 28, 2013 |website=[[CNET]] |publisher=[[CBS Interactive]] |accessdate=January 16, 2017}}</ref> In April 2012, Google's then-Senior Vice President [[Sundar Pichai]] said that Google Drive would be tightly integrated with [[Chrome OS]] version 20.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.wired.com/2012/04/google-gdrive-chrome-os |title=Google Set to Meld GDrive With Chrome OS |last=Metz |first=Cade |date=April 25, 2012 |website=[[Wired (website)|Wired]] |publisher=[[Condé Nast]] |accessdate=January 16, 2017}}</ref> In October 2016, Google announced that, going forward, it will drop support for versions of the computer software older than 1 year.<ref>{{cite web |title=Service for Google Drive for Mac/PC versions 1.27 and older ending after February 1, 2017 |url=https://gsuiteupdates.googleblog.com/2016/10/service-for-google-drive-for-mac-pc-lower-than-127-ending.html |website=G Suite Updates |publisher=[[Google]] |date=October 18, 2016 |accessdate=May 10, 2017}}</ref> In June 2017, Google announced that a new app called Backup and Sync would replace the existing separate Google Drive and Google Photos desktop apps, creating one unified app on desktop platforms.<ref name="Verge Backup and Sync" /><ref name="TNW Backup and Sync" /> Originally intended for release on June 28, its release was delayed<ref name="ap-delay">{{cite web |first=Corbin |last=Davenport |title=Google's updated Drive client for Windows and Mac delayed |url=http://www.androidpolice.com/2017/07/01/googles-updated-drive-client-windows-mac-delayed/ |website=Android Police |date=July 1, 2017 |accessdate=July 3, 2017}}</ref> until July 12.<ref name="The Verge new app">{{cite web |first=Shannon |last=Liao |title=Google releases Backup and Sync for Mac and Windows |url=https://www.theverge.com/2017/7/12/15961478/google-releases-backup-and-sync-for-mac-and-windows |website=[[The Verge]] |publisher=[[Vox Media]] |date=July 12, 2017}}</ref><ref name="Ars Technica new app">{{cite web |first=Ron |last=Amadeo |title=Google's new "Backup and Sync" app lets you back up your desktop to Drive |url=https://arstechnica.com/gadgets/2017/07/google-backup-and-sync-app-merges-the-drive-and-photos-sync-apps/ |website=[[Ars Technica]] |publisher=[[Condé Nast]] |date=July 13, 2017 |accessdate=July 13, 2017}}</ref><ref name="TechCrunch new app">{{cite web |first=Sarah |last=Perez |title=Google launches a new Backup & Sync desktop app for uploading files and photos to the cloud |url=https://techcrunch.com/2017/07/12/google-launches-a-new-backup-sync-desktop-app-for-uploading-files-and-photos-to-the-cloud/ |website=[[TechCrunch]] |publisher=[[AOL]] |date=July 12, 2017 |accessdate=July 13, 2017}}</ref> In September 2017, Google announced that it will discontinue the Google Drive desktop app in March 2018 and end support in December 2017.<ref name=":0">[https://www.theverge.com/2017/9/7/16267624/google-drive-desktop-app-shutdown The Google Drive app for PC and Mac is being shut down in March - The Verge]</ref>
==== Backup and Sync ==== In July 2017, Google announced their new downloadable software, Backup and Sync.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.blog.google/products/photos/introducing-backup-and-sync-google-photos-and-google-drive/|title=Introducing Backup and Sync for Google Photos and Google Drive|date=2017-07-12|work=Google|access-date=2017-12-07|language=en}}</ref> It was made mainly to replace the Google Drive desktop app,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.pcworld.com/article/3223136/data-center-cloud/google-drive-is-being-replaced-by-backup-and-sync-what-to-expect.html|title=Google Drive is being replaced by Backup and Sync: What to expect|work=PCWorld|access-date=2017-12-07|language=en}}</ref> which was discontinued.<ref name=":0" /> Its main function is for the user to be able to set certain folders to constantly sync onto their [[Google Account|Google account's]] Drive. The synced folders and files count against the shared quota allocated between Gmail, Google Photos, and Google Drive.
=== Mobile apps === Google Drive is available for [[Android (operating system)|Android]] [[smartphone]]s and [[Tablet computer|tablets]] running [[Android Jelly Bean|Android 4.1 "Jelly Bean"]] or later,<ref>{{cite web |title=System requirements and browsers |url=https://support.google.com/drive/answer/2375082?co=GENIE.Platform%3DAndroid&oco=1 |website=Drive Help |publisher=[[Google]] |accessdate=January 16, 2017}}</ref> and [[iPhone]]s and [[iPad]]s running [[iOS 8]] or later.<ref>{{cite web |title=System requirements and browsers |url=https://support.google.com/drive/answer/2375082?co=GENIE.Platform%3DiOS&oco=1 |website=Drive Help |publisher=[[Google]] |accessdate=January 16, 2017}}</ref>
In August 2016, Google Drive ended support for Android devices running [[Android Ice Cream Sandwich|Android 4.0 "Ice Cream Sandwich"]] or older versions,<ref>{{cite web |first=Ryan |last=Whitwam |title=Drive app update ends support for ICS, adds in-app storage upgrades, and more |url=http://www.androidpolice.com/2016/08/23/drive-app-update-ends-support-ics-adds-storage-plan-upgrades/ |website=Android Police |date=August 23, 2016 |accessdate=January 16, 2017}}</ref> citing Google's mobile app update policy, which states: "For Android devices, we provide updates for the current and 2 previous Android versions." According to the policy, the app will continue to work for devices running older Android versions, but any app updates are provided on a best-efforts basis. The policy also states a notice will be given for any planned end of service.<ref>{{cite web |title=Updates to G Suite mobile apps |url=https://support.google.com/a/answer/6288871 |website=G Suite Administrator Help |publisher=[[Google]] |accessdate=January 16, 2017}}</ref>
=== Website interface === Google Drive has a website that allows users to see their files from any Internet-connected computer, without the need to download an app.
The website received a visual overhaul in 2014 that gave it a completely new look and improved performance. It also simplified some of the most common tasks, such as clicking only once on a file to see recent activity or share the file, and added drag-and-drop functionality, where users can simply drag selected files to folders, for improved organization.<ref name="Meet the new Google Drive">{{cite web |title=Meet the new Google Drive |url=https://drive.googleblog.com/2014/06/meet-new-google-drive_25.html |website=Google Drive Blog |publisher=[[Google]] |date=June 25, 2014 |accessdate=January 16, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |first=Michael |last=Crider |title=Google Drive Gets A Shiny New Interface On The Web, Rolling Out To Users Starting Now |url=http://www.androidpolice.com/2014/07/08/google-drive-gets-a-shiny-new-interface-on-the-web-rolling-out-to-users-starting-today/ |website=Android Police |date=July 8, 2014 |accessdate=January 16, 2017}}</ref>
A new update in August 2016 changed several visual elements of the website; the logo was updated, search box design was refreshed, and the primary color was changed from red to blue. It also improved the functionality to download files locally from the website; users can now compress and download large Drive items into multiple 2 GB .zip files with an improved naming structure, better Google Forms handling, and empty folders will now be included in the [[Zip (file format)|.zip]], thereby preserving the user's folder hierarchy.<ref>{{cite web |title=Improvements to downloading files and folders in Google Drive on the web |url=https://gsuiteupdates.googleblog.com/2016/08/improvements-to-downloading-files-and-folders-in-Drive.html |website=G Suite Updates |publisher=[[Google]] |date=August 18, 2016 |accessdate=January 16, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |first=Ryan |last=Whitwam |title=Google Drive on the web gets UI tweaks, better file downloads, and more |url=http://www.androidpolice.com/2016/08/18/google-drive-web-gets-ui-tweaks-better-file-downloads/ |website=Android Police |date=August 18, 2016 |accessdate=January 16, 2017}}</ref>
== Storage == === Individual user account storage === {{Main|Google One}} Google gives every user 15 GB of free storage though [[Google One]], [[Google Docs, Sheets and Slides]] files do not count towards the storage limit.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=https://one.google.com/storage|title=Sign in - Google Accounts|website=one.google.com|language=en|access-date=2018-11-26}}</ref> This cloud storage is also shared with [[Gmail]] and [[Google Photos]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://lifehacker.com/google-one-is-now-open-for-everyone-but-is-it-a-good-d-1826049257|title=Google One Is Now Available to Everyone in the U.S., But Is It a Good Deal?|last=Murphy|first=David|work=Lifehacker|access-date=2018-11-26|language=en-US}}</ref> An unlimited number of photos at maximum 16 [[megapixel]]s and videos at maximum [[1080p]] resolutions are stored for free using the "High quality" setting in Google Photos. Using the "Original quality" setting uses Google Drive quota.<ref>{{cite web |title=Choose a storage size |url=https://support.google.com/photos/answer/6220791 |website=Google Photos Help |publisher=[[Google]] |accessdate=January 16, 2017}}</ref>
Users can purchase additional space through either a monthly or yearly payment. The option of yearly payments was introduced in December 2016, and is limited to the 100 GB or 1 TB storage plans. Furthermore, the yearly payments offer a discount.<ref>{{cite web |first=David |last=Ruddock |title=Nice: Google Drive adds annual billing - with discounts - for 100GB and 1TB plans |url=http://www.androidpolice.com/2016/12/21/nice-google-drive-adds-annual-billing-with-discounts-for-100gb-and-1tb-plans/ |website=Android Police |date=December 21, 2016 |accessdate=January 16, 2017}}</ref> In May 2018, Google announced that storage plans (including the free 15 gigabyte plan) would be moved over to [[Google One]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.blog.google/products/google-one/one-simple-way-get-more-out-google/|title=One simple way to get more out of Google|date=2018-05-14|work=Google|access-date=2018-11-26|language=en}}</ref>
{{As of|2017}}, these are the storage plans offered by Google:<ref name=":1" /> {| class="wikitable" !Storage !Price (US$) |- |15 GB |Free |- |100 GB |$1.99/month ($20.99/year) |- |200 GB |$2.99/month ($29.99/year) |- |2 TB |$9.99/month ($99.99/year) |- |10 TB |$99.99/month |- |20 TB |$199.99/month |- |30 TB |$299.99/month |}
=== Chromebook promotions === [[Chromebook]] users can obtain 100 GB of Google Drive storage free for 2 years as long as the promotion is activated within 180 days of the Chromebook device's initial purchase.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.google.com/chromebook/offers/|title=Offers – Google Chromebooks|website=Google Chromebooks|language=en-US|access-date=2017-12-07}}</ref> This is available in all countries where Google Drive is available. Offer can only be redeemed once per device. Used, open-box, and refurbished devices are not eligible for the offer.
=== G Suite storage === {{Main article|G Suite}}
Google offers 30 GB of Drive storage for all [[G Suite]] Basic customers, and unlimited storage for those using G Suite Business or G Suite for Education, as long as there are at least 5 members. Associations with less than 5 members get 1 TB per user.<ref>{{cite web |title=Options for adding Drive storage |url=https://support.google.com/a/answer/177064 |website=G Suite Administrator Help |publisher=[[Google]] |accessdate=January 16, 2017}}</ref>
=== Storage scheme revisions === Before the introduction of Google Drive, [[Google Docs, Sheets and Slides|Google Docs]] initially provided 15 GB of storage free of charge.{{citation needed|date=October 2016}} On April 24, 2012, Google Drive was introduced with free storage of 5 GB. Storage plans were revised, with 25GB costing $2.49/month, 100GB costing $4.99/month and 1TB costing $49.99/month.<ref name="Introducing Google Drive"/>
Originally, [[Gmail]], Google Docs and [[Picasa]] had separate allowances for free storage and a shared allowance for purchased storage.{{citation needed|date=October 2016}} Between April 2012 and May 2013, Google Drive and Google+ Photos had a shared allowance for both free and purchased storage, whereas Gmail had a separate 10 GB storage limit, which increased to 25 GB on the purchase of any storage plan.{{citation needed|date=October 2016}}
In September 2012, Google announced that a paid plan would now cover total storage, rather than the paid allocation being added to the free; e.g. a 100 GB plan allowed a total of 100 GB rather than 115 GB as previously.<ref>{{cite web |first=Yossi |last=Matias |title=More spring cleaning |url=https://googleblog.blogspot.no/2012/09/more-spring-cleaning.html |website=Official Google Blog |publisher=[[Google]] |date=September 28, 2012 |accessdate=October 22, 2016}}</ref>
In May 2013, Google announced the overall merge of storage across Gmail, Google Drive and Google+ Photos, allowing users 15 GB of unified free storage between the services.<ref name="Unified storage">{{cite web|url=https://drive.googleblog.com/2013/05/bringing-it-all-together-15-gb-now.html|title=Bringing it all together: 15 GB now shared between Drive, Gmail, and Google+ Photos|last=Bavor|first=Clay|date=May 13, 2013|website=Google Drive Blog|publisher=[[Google]]|accessdate=January 16, 2017}}</ref>
In March 2014, the storage plans were revised again and prices were reduced by 80% to $1.99/month for 100 GB, $9.99/month for 1TB, and $99.99/month for 10 TB.<ref>{{cite web |first=Scott |last=Johnston |title=Save more with Google Drive |url=https://drive.googleblog.com/2014/03/save-more-with-google-drive.html |website=Google Drive Blog |publisher=[[Google]] |date=March 13, 2014 |accessdate=October 22, 2016}}</ref> This was much cheaper than competitors [[Dropbox (service)|Dropbox]] and [[OneDrive]] offered at the time.<ref>{{cite web |first=Mike |last=Epstein |title=Google Drive's new prices make Dropbox, OneDrive seem like ripoffs |url=http://www.digitaltrends.com/computing/google-slashes-google-drive-prices/ |website=[[Digital Trends]] |date=March 13, 2014 |accessdate=October 22, 2016}}</ref>
In 2018, the paid plans were re-branded as '''[[Google One]]''' to emphasize their application beyond Google Drive, along with the addition of a $2.99/month plan for 200 GB, and increasing the $9.99 plan to 2 TB at no additional charge.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theverge.com/2018/8/15/17693006/google-one-cloud-storage-plans-launch|title=Google One launches with cheaper cloud storage plans|work=The Verge|access-date=2018-10-09}}</ref>
In most cases during these changes, users could continue with their existing plans as long as they kept their accounts active and did not make any adjustments to the plan. However, if the account lapsed for any reason, users had to choose from current plans.
== Features == === Sharing === Google Drive incorporates a system of file sharing in which the creator of a file or folder is, by default, its owner. The owner can regulate the public visibility of the file or folder. Ownership is transferable. Files or folders can be shared privately with particular users having a [[Google account]], using their ''@gmail.com'' email addresses. Sharing files with users not having a Google account requires making them accessible to "anybody with the link". This generates a secret URL for the file, which may be shared via email or private messages. Files and folders can also be made "public on the web", which means that they can be indexed by search engines and thus can be found and accessed by anyone. The owner may also set an access level for regulating permissions. The three access levels offered are "can edit", "can comment" and "can view". Users with editing access can invite others to edit.
=== Third-party apps === A number of external [[web application]]s that work with Google Drive are available from the [[Chrome Web Store]]. To add an app, users are required to sign into the Chrome Web Store, but the apps are compatible with all supported web browsers. Some of these apps are first-party, such as Google Docs, Sheets and Slides. Drive apps operate on the online files, and can be used to view, edit and create files in various formats, edit images and videos, fax and sign documents, manage projects, create flowcharts, etc. Drive apps can also be made the default for handling file formats supported by them. Some of these apps also work offline on [[Google Chrome]] and [[Chrome OS]].<ref name="about third-party apps">{{cite web |title=Use Google Drive apps |url=https://support.google.com/drive/answer/2500820 |website=Drive Help |publisher=[[Google]] |accessdate=October 30, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |first=Alex |last=Chitu |title=Chrome and Google Drive's Third-Party Apps |url=http://googlesystem.blogspot.no/2012/04/chrome-and-google-drives-third-party.html |date=April 25, 2012 |accessdate=October 30, 2016}}</ref>
All of the third-party apps are free to install. However, some have fees associated with continued usage or access to additional features. Saving data from a third-party app to Google Drive requires authorization the first time.<ref>{{cite web |first=Todd |last=Ogasawara |title=Google Drive Third-Party Apps: An Introduction |url=http://www.informationweek.com/consumer/google-drive-third-party-apps-an-introduction/d/d-id/1108780 |website=[[InformationWeek]] |publisher=UBM Tech |date=February 22, 2013 |accessdate=October 30, 2016}}</ref>
The Google Drive software development kit (SDK) works together with the Google Drive user interface and the Chrome Web Store to create an ecosystem of apps that can be installed into Google Drive. In February 2013, the "Create" menu in Google Drive was revamped to include third-party apps, thus effectively granting them the same status as Google's own apps.<ref>{{cite web |first=Nicolas |last=Garnier |title=Elevate your apps in Google Drive |url=https://developers.googleblog.com/2013/02/elevate-your-apps-in-google-drive.html |website=Google Developers Blog |publisher=[[Google]] |date=February 8, 2013 |accessdate=October 30, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |first=Emil |last=Protalinski |title=Google Drive's Create menu now lets you add and access third-party, Drive-enabled apps |url=https://thenextweb.com/google/2013/02/08/google-drives-create-menu-now-lets-you-add-and-access-third-party-drive-enabled-apps/ |website=The Next Web |date=February 8, 2013 |accessdate=October 30, 2016}}</ref>
In March 2013, Google released an [[Application programming interface|API]] for Google Drive that enables third-party developers to build collaborative apps that support real-time editing.<ref>{{cite web |first=Brian |last=Cairns |title=Build collaborative apps with Google Drive Realtime API |url=https://developers.googleblog.com/2013/03/build-collaborative-apps-with-google.html |website=Google Developers Blog |publisher=[[Google]] |date=March 19, 2013 |accessdate=October 30, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |first=Aaron |last=Souppouris |title=Google Drive now allows third-party apps to edit docs in realtime |url=https://www.theverge.com/2013/3/19/4123822/google-drive-realtime-api-opens-door-to-developers-to-create-drive-apps |website=[[The Verge]] |publisher=[[Vox Media]] |date=March 19, 2013 |accessdate=October 30, 2016}}</ref>
=== File viewing === The Google Drive viewer on the web allows the following file formats to be viewed:<ref name="File types and limits"/> *Native formats (Docs, Sheets, Slides, Forms, Drawings) *[[Image file formats|Image files]] (.[[JPEG]], .[[Portable Network Graphics|PNG]], .[[Graphics Interchange Format|GIF]], .[[Tagged Image File Format|TIFF]], .[[BMP file format|BMP]], .[[WebP|WEBP]]) * [[Video file format|Video files]] (.[[WebM|WEBM]], .[[MPEG-4|MPEG4]], .[[3GPP]], .[[QuickTime File Format|MOV]], .[[Audio Video Interleave|AVI]], .[[MPEG]], .[[MPEG program stream|MPEGPS]], .[[Windows Media Video|WMV]], .[[Flash Video|FLV]], .[[Ogg|OGG]]) *[[Audio file format|Audio formats]] (.[[MP3]], .[[M4A]], .[[WAV]], .[[Ogg|OGG]]) * [[Text file|Text files]] (.[[Text file|TXT]]) * Markup/Code (.[[Cascading Style Sheets|CSS]], .[[HTML]], .[[PHP]], .[[C (programming language)|C]], .[[C++|CPP]], .[[Header file|H]], .[[Header file|HPP]], .[[JavaScript|JS]]) * [[Microsoft Word]] ([[DOC (computing)|.DOC]] and [[Office Open XML|.DOCX]]) * [[Microsoft Excel]] ([[Microsoft Excel file format#File formats|.XLS and .XLSX]]) * [[Microsoft PowerPoint]] ([[PPT format|.PPT and .PPTX]]) * Adobe Portable Document Format ([[Portable Document Format|.PDF]]) * Apple Pages ([[Pages (iWork)|.PAGES]]) * Adobe Illustrator ([[Adobe Illustrator Artwork|.AI]]) * Adobe Photoshop ([[Adobe Photoshop#File format|.PSD]]) * Autodesk AutoCad ([[AutoCAD DXF|.DXF]]) * Scalable Vector Graphics ([[Scalable Vector Graphics|.SVG]]) * PostScript ([[PostScript|.EPS, .PS]]) * Fonts ([[TrueType|.TTF]]) * XML Paper Specification ([[Open XML Paper Specification|.XPS]]) * Archive file types ([[Zip (file format)|.ZIP]], [[.RAR]], [[tar (computing)|tar]], [[gzip]]) *.[[.m2ts|MTS]] files *Raw Image formats
Files in other formats can also be handled through third-party apps that work with Google Drive, available from the [[Chrome Web Store]].<ref name="about third-party apps"/>
=== File limits === Files uploaded, but not converted to [[Google Docs, Sheets and Slides|Google Docs, Sheets, or Slides]] formats, may be up to 5 TB in size. There are also limits, specific to file type, listed below:<ref name="File types and limits">{{cite web |title=Files you can store in Google Drive |url=https://support.google.com/drive/answer/37603 |website=Drive Help |publisher=[[Google]] |accessdate=October 22, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Insert or delete images or videos |url=https://support.google.com/docs/answer/97447 |website=Docs editors Help |publisher=[[Google]] |accessdate=October 22, 2016}}</ref>
;Documents (Google Docs): Up to 1.02 million characters, regardless of the number of pages or font size. Document files converted to .gdoc Docs format cannot be larger than 50 MB. Images inserted cannot be larger than 50 MB, and must be in either .jpg, .png, or non-animated .gif formats.
;Spreadsheets (Google Sheets): Up to 2 million cells.
;Presentations (Google Slides): Presentation files converted to .gslides Slides format cannot be larger than 100 MB. Images inserted cannot be larger than 50 MB, and must be in either .jpg, .png, or non-animated .gif formats.
=== Quick Access === Introduced in the Android app in September 2016, Quick Access uses [[machine learning]] to "intelligently predict the files you need before you've even typed anything".<ref>{{cite web |first=Cayden |last=Meyer |title=Save time with Quick Access in Drive |url=https://blog.google/products/drive/save-time-with-quick-access-in-drive/ |website=The Keyword Google Blog |publisher=[[Google]] |date=September 29, 2016 |accessdate=February 22, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |first=Corbin |last=Davenport |title=Google Drive adds Quick Access feature, guesses what file you might want |url=http://www.androidpolice.com/2016/09/29/google-drive-adds-quick-access-feature-available-g-suite-customers/ |website=Android Police |date=September 29, 2016 |accessdate=February 22, 2017}}</ref> The feature was announced to be expanded to [[iOS]] and the [[Web application|web]] in March 2017,<ref>{{cite web |first=Jordan |last=Novet |title=Google revamps Drive with File Stream and expanded Quick Access, launches Gmail add-ons |url=https://venturebeat.com/2017/03/09/google-revamps-drive-with-file-stream-and-expanded-quick-access-launches-gmail-add-ons/ |website=[[VentureBeat]] |date=March 9, 2017 |accessdate=March 10, 2017}}</ref> though the website interface received the feature in May.<ref>{{cite web |first=Ryne |last=Hager |title=The Quick Access feature in Google Drive for Android is coming to Drive on the web |url=http://www.androidpolice.com/2017/05/18/quick-access-feature-google-drive-android-coming-drive-web/ |website=Android Police |date=May 18, 2017 |accessdate=May 19, 2017}}</ref>
=== Search === Search results can be narrowed by file type, ownership, visibility, and the open-with app. Users can search for images by describing or naming what is in them. For example, a search for "mountain" returns all the photos of mountains, as well as any text documents about mountains.<ref>{{cite web |first=Nicolas |last=Garnier |title=How to make files searchable in Google Drive |url=https://gsuite-developers.googleblog.com/2013/02/how-to-make-files-searchable-in-google.html |website=G Suite Developers Blog |publisher=[[Google]] |date=February 27, 2013 |accessdate=November 12, 2016}}</ref> Text in images and [[PDF]]s can be extracted using [[optical character recognition]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Convert PDF and photo files to text |url=https://support.google.com/drive/answer/176692 |website=Drive Help |publisher=[[Google]] |accessdate=March 20, 2017}}</ref> In September 2016, Google added "natural language processing" for searching on the Google Drive website, enabling specific user search queries like "find my budget spreadsheet from last December".<ref>{{cite web |first=Josh |last=Smith |title=What you love about Google Search—now for Drive |url=https://blog.google/products/drive/what-you-love-about-google-search-now/ |website=The Keyword Google Blog |publisher=[[Google]] |date=September 20, 2016 |accessdate=November 12, 2016}}</ref> In February 2017, Google integrated Drive and the Google Search app on Android, letting users search for keywords, switch to an "In Apps" tab, and see any relevant Drive files.<ref>{{cite web |first=Napier |last=Lopez |title=Android users can now find Google Drive files right in Search |url=https://thenextweb.com/google/2017/02/23/android-users-can-now-find-google-drive-files-right-search/ |website=The Next Web |date=February 23, 2017 |accessdate=March 27, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |first=Eric |last=Ravenscraft |title=You Can Now Use Google to Search Your Drive Files On Android |url=http://lifehacker.com/you-can-now-use-google-to-search-your-drive-files-on-an-1792699850 |website=[[Lifehacker]] |publisher=[[Univision Communications]] |date=February 24, 2017 |accessdate=March 27, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |first=Lulu |last=Chang |title=You can now find your Google Drive files directly through the Android Google app |url=http://www.digitaltrends.com/mobile/android-google-app-drive/ |website=[[Digital Trends]] |date=February 24, 2017 |accessdate=March 27, 2017}}</ref>
=== Backups === In December 2016, Google updated the Android app and website with a "Backups" section, listing the Android device and app backups saved to Drive. The section lets users see what backups are stored, the backups' sizes and details, and delete backups.<ref>{{cite web |first=Rita |last=El Khoury |title=[Update: Available on Android] Google Drive Backups tab starts showing up, gives you a glimpse into your device and app backups |url=http://www.androidpolice.com/2016/12/08/google-drive-backups-tab-starts-showing-gives-glimpse-device-app-backups/ |website=Android Police |date=December 8, 2016 |accessdate=January 16, 2017}}</ref>
In June 2017, Google announced that a new app, "Backup and Sync", would be able to synchronize any folder on the user's computer to Google.<ref name="Verge Backup and Sync">{{cite web |first=Jacob |last=Kastrenakes |title=Google Drive will soon back up your entire computer |url=https://www.theverge.com/2017/6/14/15802200/google-backup-and-sync-app-announced-drive-feature |website=[[The Verge]] |publisher=[[Vox Media]] |date=June 14, 2017 |accessdate=June 15, 2017}}</ref><ref name="TNW Backup and Sync">{{cite web |first=Abhimanyu |last=Ghoshal |title=Google Drive will automatically back up your hard drive later this month |url=https://thenextweb.com/apps/2017/06/15/google-drive-will-automatically-back-up-your-hard-drive-later-this-month/ |website=The Next Web |date=June 15, 2017 |accessdate=June 15, 2017}}</ref> The app was released on July 12, 2017.<ref name="The Verge new app"/><ref name="Ars Technica new app"/><ref name="TechCrunch new app"/>
=== Metadata === A Description field is available for both files and folders that users can use to add relevant metadata. Content within the Description field is also indexed by Google Drive and searchable.<ref>{{cite web |first=Rebecca |last=Steelman |title=Tips & Tricks: Using the description field in your documents list |url=https://drive.googleblog.com/2011/06/tips-tricks-using-description-field-in.html |website=Google Drive Blog |publisher=[[Google]] |date=June 14, 2011 |accessdate=March 20, 2017}}</ref>
=== Accessibility to the visually impaired === In June 2014, Google announced a number of updates to Google Drive, which included making the service more accessible to visually impaired users. This included improved keyboard accessibility, support for zooming and high contrast mode, and better compatibility with screen readers.<ref name="Meet the new Google Drive"/>
=== ''Save to Google Drive'' browser extension === Google offers an [[Google Chrome Extensions|extension for Google Chrome]], ''Save to Google Drive'', that allows users to save web content to Google Drive through a browser action or through the context menu. While documents and images can be saved directly, webpages can be saved in the form of a [[screenshot]] (as an image of the visible part of the page or the entire page), or as a raw [[HTML]], [[MHTML]], or Google Docs file. Users need to be signed into Chrome to use the extension.<ref>{{cite web |title=Save to Google Drive |url=https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/save-to-google-drive/gmbmikajjgmnabiglmofipeabaddhgne |website=[[Chrome Web Store]] |publisher=[[Google]] |accessdate=July 29, 2014}}</ref>
=== Mobile apps === The main Google Drive mobile app supported editing of documents and spreadsheets until April 2014, when the capability was moved to separate, standalone apps for [[Google Docs]], [[Google Sheets]], and [[Google Slides]].<ref>{{cite web |first=Brian |last=Levee |title=New mobile apps for Docs, Sheets and Slides - work offline and on the go |url=https://googleblog.blogspot.no/2014/04/new-mobile-apps-for-docs-sheets-and.html |website=Official Google Blog |publisher=[[Google]] |date=April 30, 2014 |accessdate=January 16, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |first=Bogdan |last=Petrovan |title=Google launches standalone Docs, Sheets, and Slides apps for Android |url=http://www.androidauthority.com/google-docs-sheets-slides-2-375092/ |website=Android Authority |date=April 30, 2014 |accessdate=January 16, 2017}}</ref> The Google Drive app on Android allows users to take a photo of a document, sign, or other text and use [[optical character recognition]] to convert to text that can be edited.<ref>{{cite web |first=Reuben |last=Kan |title=Introducing the new Google Docs app for Android |url=http://googlemobile.blogspot.no/2011/04/introducing-new-google-docs-app-for.html |website=Google Mobile Blog |publisher=[[Google]] |date=April 27, 2011 |accessdate=January 16, 2017}}</ref> In October 2014, the Android app was updated with a [[Material Design]] user interface, improved search, the ability to add a custom message while sharing a file, and a new PDF viewer.<ref>{{cite web |title=New version of the Google Drive app for Android |url=https://gsuiteupdates.googleblog.com/2014/10/new-version-of-google-drive-app-for.html |website=G Suite Updates |publisher=[[Google]] |date=October 29, 2014 |accessdate=January 16, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |first=Liam |last=Spradlin |title=A Look At Google Drive's Material Design In Android 5.0 Lollipop |url=http://www.androidpolice.com/2014/10/21/a-look-at-google-drives-material-design-in-android-5-0-lollipop/ |website=Android Police |date=October 21, 2014 |accessdate=January 16, 2017}}</ref>
=== Encryption === Before 2013, Google did not [[encrypt]] data stored on its servers. Following information that the United States' [[National Security Agency]] had "direct access" to servers owned by multiple technology companies, including Google,<ref>{{cite web |first1=Glenn |last1=Greenwald |first2=Ewen |last2=MacAskill |title=NSA Prism program taps in to user data of Apple, Google and others |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/jun/06/us-tech-giants-nsa-data |website=[[The Guardian]] |publisher=[[Guardian Media Group]] |date=June 7, 2013 |accessdate=June 10, 2017}}</ref> the company began testing encrypting data in July<ref>{{cite web |first=Declan |last=McCullaugh |title=Google tests encryption to protect users' Drive files against government demands |url=https://www.cnet.com/news/google-tests-encryption-to-protect-users-drive-files-against-government-demands/ |website=[[CNET]] |publisher=[[CBS Interactive]] |date=July 17, 2013 |accessdate=June 10, 2017}}</ref> and enabled encryption for data in transit between its data centers in November.<ref>{{cite web |first=Sean |last=Gallagher |title=Googlers say “F*** you” to NSA, company encrypts internal network |url=https://arstechnica.com/information-technology/2013/11/googlers-say-f-you-to-nsa-company-encrypts-internal-network/ |website=[[Ars Technica]] |publisher=[[Condé Nast]] |date=November 6, 2013 |accessdate=June 10, 2017}}</ref> However, as of 2015, Google Drive does not provide [[client-side encryption]].<ref>{{cite web |first=Tom |last=McNamara |title=How to make Google Drive more secure |url=http://download.cnet.com/blog/download-blog/how-to-make-google-drive-more-secure/ |website=[[CNET]] |publisher=[[CBS Interactive]] |date=July 8, 2015 |accessdate=June 10, 2017}}</ref>
== Professional editions == {{See also|G Suite}}
=== Google Drive for Work === Google Drive for Work is a business version, a part of [[G Suite]] (formerly Google Apps for Work), announced at the [[Google I/O]] conference on June 25, 2014 and made available immediately. The service features unlimited storage, advanced file audit reporting and eDiscovery services, along with enhanced administration control and new [[Application programming interface|APIs]] specifically useful to businesses. Users can upload files as large as 5 TB.<ref>{{cite web |first=Bryan |last=Bishop |title=Google announces Drive for Work with unlimited storage at $10 a month |url=https://www.theverge.com/2014/6/25/5842108/google-announces-drive-for-work-with-unlimited-storage-at-10-a-month |website=[[The Verge]] |publisher=[[Vox Media]] |date=June 25, 2014 |accessdate=October 23, 2016}}</ref> A press release posted on Google's Official Enterprise Blog assured businesses that Google will encrypt data stored on its servers, as well as information being transmitted to or from them. Google will deliver 24/7 phone support to business users and has guaranteed 99.9% uptime for its servers.<ref>{{cite web |first=Scott |last=Johnston |title=Unlimit your business with Google Drive for Work |url=https://cloud.googleblog.com/2014/06/unlimit-your-business-with-google-drive.html |website=Official Google Cloud Blog |publisher=[[Google]] |date=June 25, 2014 |accessdate=November 12, 2016}}</ref>
In September 2015, Google announced that Google Drive for Work would be compliant with the new ISO/IEC 27018:2014 security and privacy standard, which confirmed that Google would not use data in Drive for Work accounts for advertising, enabled additional tools for handling and exporting data, more transparency about data storage, and protection from third-party data requests.<ref>{{cite web |first=Marc |last=Crandall |title=Google Apps for Work adopts ISO 27018 cloud privacy standard |url=https://cloud.googleblog.com/2015/09/Google-Apps-for-Work-adopts-ISO-27018-cloud-privacy-standard.html |website=Official Google Cloud Blog |publisher=[[Google]] |date=September 21, 2015 |accessdate=October 28, 2016}}</ref>
In March 2017, Google introduced Drive File Stream, making it possible for G Suite customers on [[Microsoft Windows|Windows]] and [[macOS]] computers to search their Drive folders and download specific files on-demand rather than downloading all files during installation, potentially preventing large amounts of data from "gobbling up your hard drive". Additionally, the feature will guess what files users need in the future and download those files as well.<ref>{{cite web |first=Alex |last=Vogenthaler |title=Introducing new, enterprise-ready tools for Google Drive |url=https://blog.google/products/g-suite/introducing-new-enterprise-ready-tools-google-drive/ |website=The Keyword Google Blog |publisher=[[Google]] |date=March 9, 2017 |accessdate=March 10, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |first=Ryan |last=Whitwam |title=Drive File Stream for G Suite lets you access all your files without using all your disk space |url=http://www.androidpolice.com/2017/03/09/drive-file-stream-g-suite-lets-access-files-without-using-disk-space/ |website=Android Police |date=March 9, 2017 |accessdate=March 10, 2017}}</ref>
=== Google Drive for Education === Google Drive for Education was announced on September 30, 2014. It was made available for free to all Google Apps for Education users. It includes unlimited storage and support for individual files up to 5TB in size in addition to full encryption.<ref>{{cite web |first=Nick |last=Summers |title=Google unveils Drive for Education with free, unlimited storage and 'Classroom' integration |url=https://thenextweb.com/google/2014/09/30/google-unveils-drive-education-free-unlimited-storage-automatic-file-encryption/ |website=The Next Web |date=September 30, 2014 |accessdate=October 23, 2016}}</ref>
=== Team Drives === In September 2016, Google announced Team Drives, a new way for teams to collaborate. Sharing and file ownership are managed for the entire team rather than one individual, and new users instantly get access to all files and information.<ref>{{cite web |title=New Early Adopter Programs: Team Drives and a new Hangouts video meetings experience |url=https://gsuiteupdates.googleblog.com/2016/09/new-early-adopter-programs-team-drives.html |website=G Suite Updates |publisher=[[Google]] |date=September 29, 2016 |accessdate=January 4, 2017}}</ref> In November, Google opened an Early Adopter Program, allowing G Suite Business and G Suite for Education customers to sign up, although Google noted that some functionality isn't yet supported by Team Drives.<ref>{{cite web |title=Google Team Drives Early Adopter Program now accepting applications |url=https://gsuiteupdates.googleblog.com/2016/11/google-team-drives-early-adopter.html |website=G Suite Updates |publisher=[[Google]] |date=November 21, 2016 |accessdate=January 4, 2017}}</ref>
== Docs, Sheets and Slides ==
[[Google Docs]], [[Google Sheets]], [[Google Slides]], and [[Google Forms]] constitute a free, web-based office suite offered by Google and integrated with Google Drive. It allows users to create and edit documents, spreadsheets, and presentations online while collaborating in real-time with other users. The three apps are available as [[web application]]s, as [[Chrome app]]s that work offline, and as [[mobile app]]s for Android and iOS. The apps are compatible with [[Microsoft Office]] file formats. The suite also consists of [[Google Forms]], [[Google Drawings]] and [[Google Fusion Tables]]. While Forms and Tables are only available as web applications, Drawings is also available as a Chrome app. The suite is tightly integrated with Google Drive, and all files created with the apps are by default saved to Google Drive.
===Updates===
Updates to Docs, Sheets, Slides, and Forms have introduced features using [[machine learning]], including "Explore", offering search results based on the contents of a document, answers based on [[Natural language processing|natural language]] questions in a spreadsheet, and dynamic design suggestions based on contents of a slideshow, and "Action items", allowing users to assign tasks to other users. While Google Docs has been criticized for lacking the functionality of [[Microsoft Office]], it has received praise for its simplicity, ease of collaboration and frequent product updates.
In order to view and edit Docs, Sheets, or Slides documents offline, users need to be using the Google Chrome web browser. A [[Google Chrome#Extensions|Chrome extension]], ''Google Docs Offline'', allows users to enable offline support for Docs, Sheets and Slides files on the Google Drive website.<ref>{{cite web |title=Work on Google files offline |url=https://support.google.com/drive/answer/2375012 |website=Drive Help |publisher=[[Google]] |accessdate=January 14, 2017}}</ref>
Google also offers an extension for the Google Chrome web browser called ''Office editing for Docs, Sheets and Slides'' that enables users to view and edit Microsoft Office documents on Google Chrome, via the Docs, Sheets and Slides apps. The extension can be used for opening Office files stored on the computer using Chrome, as well as for opening Office files encountered on the web (in the form of email attachments, web search results, etc.) without having to download them. The extension is installed on Chrome OS by default.<ref>{{cite web |title=Office Editing for Docs, Sheets & Slides |url=https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/office-editing-for-docs-s/gbkeegbaiigmenfmjfclcdgdpimamgkj |website=[[Chrome Web Store]] |publisher=[[Google]] |accessdate=October 30, 2016}}</ref>
==Google Drawings==
Google Drawings allows users to collaborate creating, sharing, and editing images or drawings. Google Drawings can be used for creating charts, diagrams, designs, flow-charts, etc. It contains a subset of the features in Google Slides but with different templates. Its features include laying out drawings precisely with alignment guides, snap to grid, auto distribution, and inserting drawings into other Google documents, spreadsheets, or presentations.<ref>{{cite web |title=Create & edit drawings |url=https://support.google.com/docs/answer/179740 |website=Docs editors Help |publisher=[[Google]] |accessdate=October 30, 2016}}</ref>
== Reception == === Features === In a review of Google Drive after its launch in April 2012, Dan Grabham of ''[[TechRadar]]'' wrote that the integration of Google Docs into Google Drive was "a bit confusing", mainly due to the differences in the [[user interface]]s between the two, where Drive offers a "My Drive" section with a specific "Shared with me" view for shared documents. He stated that "We think the user interface needs a lot more work. It's like a retread of Google Docs at the moment and Google surely needs to do work here". He considered uploading files "fairly easy", but noted that folder upload was only supported through the [[Google Chrome]] web browser. The lack of native editing of [[Microsoft Office]] documents was "annoying". Regarding Google Drive's computer apps, he stated that the option in Settings to synchronize only specific folders was "powerful". He wrote that Drive was "a great addition to Google armoury of apps and everything does work seamlessly", while again criticizing the interface for being "confusing" and that the file view was "not quite intuitive enough" without file icons. Grabham also reviewed the mobile Android app, writing that "it's a pretty simple app that enables you to access your files on the move and save some for offline access should you wish", and praised Google Docs creation and photo uploading for being "easy". He also praised that "everything is easily searchable".<ref>{{cite web |first=Dan |last=Grabham |title=Hands on: Google Drive review |url=http://www.techradar.com/news/internet/web/hands-on-google-drive-review-1077614 |website=[[TechRadar]] |publisher=[[Future plc]] |date=April 27, 2012 |accessdate=March 18, 2017}}</ref>
A review by Michael Muchmore of ''[[PC Magazine]]'' in February 2016 praised the service as "truly impressive" in creating and editing files, describing its features as "leading" in office-suite collaboration. He added that "Compatibility is rarely an issue", with importing and exporting options, and that the free storage of 15 [[gigabyte]]s was "generous". However, he also criticized the user interface for being confusing to navigate, and wrote that "Offline editing isn't simple".<ref>{{cite web |first=Michael |last=Muchmore |title=Google Drive |url=http://uk.pcmag.com/google-drive/15854/review/google-drive |website=[[PC Magazine]] |publisher=[[Ziff Davis]] |date=February 23, 2016 |accessdate=March 18, 2017}}</ref>
The Android version of Google Drive has been criticized for requiring users to individually toggle each file for use offline instead of allowing entire folders to be stored offline.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.labnol.org/software/android-file-shortcuts-google-drive/31351/|title=How to Place Files Shortcuts on Android Home Screen with Google Drive|website=www.labnol.org|language=en-US|access-date=2018-11-10}}</ref>
=== Ownership and licensing === Immediately after its announcement in April 2012, Google faced criticism over Google Drive privacy. In particular, privacy advocates have noted that Google has one unified set of Terms of Service and Privacy Policy agreements for all its products and services. In a ''[[CNET]]'' report, Zack Whittaker noted that "the terms and service have come under heavy fire by the wider community for how it handles users' copyright and intellectual property rights". In a comparison of Terms of Service agreements between Google Drive and competing cloud storage services [[Dropbox (service)|Dropbox]] and [[OneDrive]], he cited a paragraph stating that Google has broad rights to reproduce, use, and create [[derivative work]]s from content stored on Google Drive, via a license from its users. Although the user retains intellectual property rights, the user licenses Google to extract and parse uploaded content to customize advertising and other services that Google provides to the user, and to promote the service. Summarized, he wrote that "According to its terms, Google does not own user-uploaded files to Google Drive, but the company can do whatever it likes with them".<ref>{{cite web |first=Zack |last=Whittaker |title=Who owns your files on Google Drive? |url=https://www.cnet.com/news/who-owns-your-files-on-google-drive/ |website=[[CNET]] |publisher=[[CBS Interactive]] |date=May 29, 2014 |accessdate=October 30, 2016}}</ref> In a highly critical editorial of the service, Ed Bott of ''[[ZDNet]]'' wrote that language in the agreements contained "exact same words" as Dropbox used in a July 2011 Privacy Policy update that sparked criticism and forced Dropbox to update its policy once again with clarifying language, adding that "It's a perfect example of Google's inability to pay even the slightest bit of attention to anything that happens outside the Googleplex".<ref>{{cite web |first=Ed |last=Bott |title=Google clones Dropbox: lock, stock, and privacy gaffe |url=http://www.zdnet.com/article/google-clones-dropbox-lock-stock-and-privacy-gaffe/ |website=[[ZDNet]] |publisher=[[CBS Interactive]] |date=April 24, 2012 |accessdate=March 19, 2017}}</ref> Matt Peckham of ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' criticized the lack of unique service agreements for Drive, writing that "If any Google service warrants privacy firewalling, it’s Google Drive. This isn’t YouTube or Calendar or even Gmail——the potential for someone’s most sensitive data to be snooped, whether to glean info for marketing or otherwise, is too high. [...] Google ought to create a privacy exception that “narrows the scope” of its service terms for Google Drive, one that minimally states the company will never circulate the information generated from searching {{sic|''within''}} your G-Drive data in any way."<ref>{{cite web |first=Matt |last=Peckham |title=Will Google Drive Snoop Inside Your Data? Google Needs to Be Clearer |url=http://techland.time.com/2012/04/26/will-google-drive-snoop-inside-your-data-google-needs-to-be-clearer/ |website=[[Time (magazine)|Time]] |publisher=[[Time Inc.]] |date=April 26, 2012 |accessdate=March 19, 2017}}</ref>
In contrast, a report by Nilay Patel of ''[[The Verge]]'' stated that "all web services should be subject to harsh scrutiny of their privacy policies—but a close and careful reading reveals that Google's terms are pretty much the same as anyone else's, and slightly better in some cases", pointing to the fact that Google "couldn't move files around on its servers, cache your data, or make image thumbnails" without proper rights. In comparing the policies with competing services, Patel wrote that "it's clear that they need the exact same permissions—they just use slightly more artful language to communicate them".<ref>{{cite web |first=Nilay |last=Patel |title=Is Google Drive worse for privacy than iCloud, Skydrive, and Dropbox? |url=https://www.theverge.com/2012/4/25/2973849/google-drive-terms-privacy-data-skydrive-dropbox-icloud |website=[[The Verge]] |publisher=[[Vox Media]] |date=April 25, 2012 |accessdate=October 30, 2016}}</ref>
== Growth == On November 12, 2013, Google announced that Google Drive had 120 million active users, a figure that the company was releasing for the first time.<ref>{{cite web |first=Sarah |last=Perez |title=Gmail Users No Longer Need To Download Attachments, As Google Drive Gets Baked Into The Inbox |url=https://techcrunch.com/2013/11/12/gmail-users-no-longer-need-to-download-attachments-as-google-drive-gets-baked-into-the-inbox/ |website=[[TechCrunch]] |publisher=[[AOL]] |date=November 12, 2013 |accessdate=October 30, 2016}}</ref>
On June 25, 2014 at the [[Google I/O]] developer conference, [[Sundar Pichai]] announced that Google Drive now had 190 million monthly active users, and that it was being used by 58% of the [[Fortune 500]] companies as well as by 72 of the top universities.<ref>{{cite web |first=Kia |last=Kokalitcheva |title=Google Drive now has 190M users & a brand new tablet app for presentations |url=https://venturebeat.com/2014/06/25/google-drive-now-has-190m-users-a-brand-new-tablet-app-for-presentations/ |website=[[VentureBeat]] |date=June 25, 2014 |accessdate=October 30, 2016}}</ref>
On October 1, 2014, at its Atmosphere Live event, it was announced that Google Drive had 240 million monthly active users. ''The Next Web'' noted that this meant an increase of 50 million users in just one quarter.<ref>{{cite web |first=Emil |last=Protalinski |title=Google announces 10% price cut for all Compute Engine instances, Google Drive has passed 240M active users |url=https://thenextweb.com/google/2014/10/01/google-announces-10-price-cut-compute-engine-instances-google-drive-passed-240m-active-users/ |website=The Next Web |date=October 1, 2014 |accessdate=October 30, 2016}}</ref>
On September 21, 2015, it was announced that Google Drive had over one million organizational paying users.<ref>{{cite web |first=Scott |last=Johnston |title=Making Google Drive the safest place for all your work |url=https://medium.com/@gsuite/making-google-drive-the-safest-place-for-all-your-work-b5248f9b9ddc |website=[[Medium (website)|Medium]] |date=September 21, 2015 |accessdate=October 28, 2016}}</ref>
In March 2017, Google announced that Google Drive had 800 million active users.<ref>{{cite web |first=Frederic |last=Lardinois |title=Google updates Drive with a focus on its business users |url=https://techcrunch.com/2017/03/09/google-drive-now-has-800m-users-and-gets-a-big-update-for-the-enterprise/ |website=[[TechCrunch]] |publisher=[[AOL]] |date=March 9, 2017 |accessdate=May 10, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |first=Larry |last=Dignan |title=Google plans to leverage G Drive for broader enterprise footprint, team management and collaboration |url=http://www.zdnet.com/article/google-plans-to-leverage-g-drive-for-broader-enterprise-footprint-team-management-and-collaboration/ |website=[[ZDNet]] |publisher=[[CBS Interactive]] |date=March 9, 2017 |accessdate=March 10, 2017}}</ref>
In May 2017, a Google executive stated at a company event that there were over two trillion files stored on Google Drive.<ref>{{cite web |first=Rob |last=Price |title=Google Drive now hosts more than 2 trillion files |url=http://nordic.businessinsider.com/2-trillion-files-google-drive-exec-prabhakar-raghavan-2017-5 |website=[[Business Insider]] |publisher=[[Axel Springer SE]] |date=May 6, 2017 |accessdate=May 10, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |first=Matthew |last=Humphries |title=Google Drive Passes 2 Trillion Files Stored |url=http://uk.pcmag.com/cloud-services/89223/news/google-drive-passes-2-trillion-files-stored |website=[[PC Magazine]] |publisher=[[Ziff David]] |date=May 8, 2017 |accessdate=May 10, 2017}}</ref>
== Downtime issues == Although Google has a 99.9% uptime guarantee for Google Drive for [[G Suite]] customers,<ref>{{cite web |title=Reliability |url=https://support.google.com/work/answer/6056635 |website=Google Cloud Help |publisher=[[Google]] |accessdate=December 11, 2016}}</ref> Google Drive has suffered downtimes for both consumers and business users. During significant downtimes, Google's App Status Dashboard gets updated with the current status of each service Google offers, along with details on restoration progress. Notable downtimes occurred in March 2013<ref>{{cite web |first=Sarah |last=Perez |title=Google Drive Experiencing Outage (UPDATE: Google Says Resolved) |url=https://techcrunch.com/2013/03/18/google-drive-experiencing-intermittent-issues/ |website=[[TechCrunch]] |publisher=[[AOL]] |date=March 18, 2013 |accessdate=December 11, 2016}}</ref>, October 2014<ref>{{cite web |first=Ben |last=Woods |title=Google Drive and Docs are down for some users, company is investigating [Update: Fixed now!] |url=https://thenextweb.com/google/2014/10/27/google-drive-docs-users-company-investigating/ |website=The Next Web |date=October 27, 2014 |accessdate=December 11, 2016}}</ref>, January 2016<ref>{{cite web |first=Andrew |last=Griffin |title=Gmail, Google Drive down: Many Google services hit by widespread outage |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/gadgets-and-tech/news/gmail-google-drive-down-many-google-services-hit-by-widespread-outage-a6834711.html |website=[[The Independent]] |date=January 26, 2016 |accessdate=December 11, 2016}}</ref><ref name="January 2016 service outage">{{cite web |first=Ben |last=Woods |title=Google Drive and Gmail are down for some users around the world (Update: They’re back!) |url=https://thenextweb.com/google/2016/01/26/google-drive-is-down-for-some-users-around-the-world/ |website=The Next Web |date=January 26, 2016 |accessdate=December 11, 2016}}</ref>, and September 2017.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://thenextweb.com/google/2017/09/12/google-down-gmail-youtube-maps/|title=Google suffered a meltdown as Gmail, Maps and YouTube went down|last=Mix|date=2017-09-12|work=The Next Web|access-date=2017-12-07|language=en-US}}</ref>
When the January 2016 outage was resolved, a Google spokesperson told ''The Next Web'':<ref name="January 2016 service outage"/> <blockquote> At Google we recognize that failures are statistically inevitable, and we strive to insulate our users from the effects of failures. As that did not happen in this instance, we apologize to everyone who was inconvenienced by this event. Our engineers are conducting a post-mortem investigation to determine how to make our services more resilient to unplanned network failures, and we will do our utmost to continue to make Google service outages notable for their rarity. </blockquote>
In an outage that affected all of Google's services for 5 minutes in August 2013, [[CNET]] reported that global Internet traffic dropped 40%.<ref>{{cite web |first=Joe |last=Svetlik |title=Google goes down for 5 minutes, Internet traffic drops 40% |url=https://www.cnet.com/news/google-goes-down-for-5-minutes-internet-traffic-drops-40/ |website=[[CNET]] |publisher=[[CBS Interactive]] |date=August 19, 2013 |accessdate=December 11, 2016}}</ref>
